Comments_List: I learned any incredible amount of the politics surrounding nuclear weapons in this course. In addition to learning a great deal about the history of nuclear weapons, I learned about nuclear strategy, in addition to specific nuclear crises.
Issues behind nuclear proliferation and the theories behind them
A knowledge on the history of nuclear crises and development, as well as the theories on the causes of proliferation and deterrence.

I learned a ton about nuclear politics, historically and the theory behind how it influences the world today. Its very insightful especially with regards to Indian-Pakistani relations as well as the North Korean situation.
I learned a lot about nuclear weapons throughout history, the development of the Cold War, growing nuclear powers, and game theory.
I learned about the world structure of nuclear politics.
I thought the course was overall fantastic. I may incorporate a few more activities throughout the semester as opposed to having each class be a lecture.

The course is rather long and can sometimes be dull. I think this can be improved by reducing the time of the course to 50 minutes, or an hour at most. Perhaps it could be offered as a once-a-week kind of class as well. However, I feel that the class is very clearly and organically structured.
I thought the lectures were good. The response memos were annoying. The instructions for the assignments  were vague and the readings, although interesting, at times could be fairly dense and long.

I thought this was a well put together course. The assigned readings were a reasonable length and there were optional readings each week for students who wanted to know more about the subject. Each student was assigned two weeks to do reading responses, so there wasn't an overwhelming amount of work.
The course is well-structured in the historical sense, but with not too much application to the current affairs.
Yes, very fun class. Debs is a great professor and interesting topic.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in understanding nuclear politics or an interesting application of game theory.
I would recommend this course because the knowledge it conveys and the historical aspect.
